thread.title: Jacob Phillips, 4-star LB, receives Oregon Ducks offer, sets unofficial visit
thread.title_full: Jacob Phillips, 4-star LB, receives Oregon Ducks offer, sets unofficial visit | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Nemec | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Jacob Phillips, 4-star LB, receives Oregon Ducks offer, sets unofficial visit
text:
Despite having as many as four class of 2016 commitments who could grow into the linebacker position – La'Mar Winston, Darrian Franklin, Hunter Kampmoyer and Troy Dye – the Oregon Ducks are still in pursuit of a number of the nation's top players who could man the middle of the defense.
Five-star talent Caleb Kelly and four-star prospect Keith Simms , who are both visiting Oregon this weekend, are just two of the many linebackers the Ducks have offered and still have a shot at landing.
But even in the midst of a series of 2016 recruiting battles, Oregon is already in search of elite 2017 options.
On Thursday, Rivals four-star inside linebacker Jacob Phillips announced on Twitter that he had received an offer from the Ducks:
I am very blessed to recieve my 9th offer from Oregon University #Ducks pic.twitter.com/lptIgd4oY2
— Jacob Phillips (@jacobphillips_1) October 8, 2015
"I was definitely excited. It was an offer that I've been praying for," he said. "I'm blessed to have it come to fruition that I was offered by them."
Although the 6-foot-3, 231-pound junior prospect, out of East Nashville Magnet (Nashville, Tennessee), admitted he is unfamiliar with the inner workings of the Oregon program, Phillips has a personal connection that he expects to provide an insider's perspective.
"I don't know that much about Oregon. I know they have a nice program – just from seeing them in the top rankings and on (television) all the time," he said. "I used to train with ( Ugo Amadi ), so I'll have a lot of insight on all things football and about the school. I'll see how it really is up there."
Phillips expects to lean heavily on Amadi to help get him up to speed on what Oregon has to offer.
"I don't have a talk-everyday-type of relationship with him. We trained. We worked out when he was here," the linebacker said. "He's a real good guy, and I know he wouldn't lead me wrong if I asked him questions."
Even before that conversation takes place, however, Phillips has scheduled an unofficial visit to Eugene.
"I'm going out there for the USC game (on November 21)," he explained.
Phillips, who is rated the No. 8 inside linebacker in the nation by Rivals, also holds offers from Illinois, Kentucky, Oklahoma, Ole Miss, Tennessee, Vanderbilt and others, so there is already plenty of competition for the dynamic playmaker.
Still, after flipping Amadi from LSU in the class of 2015 , Oregon has proven it can snag talent out of Tennessee.
Can the Ducks do it again in 2017?
"Moving doesn't bother me at all. I don't think it will bother my family that much either. They want what's best for me, and whatever program fits me the best," Phillips said. "I have no problem going to Japan if thats' it."
-- Andrew Nemec
anemec@oregonian.com
@ AndrewNemec
